review.title: Distributed Graph Coloring: An Approach Based on the Calling Behavior of Japanese Tree Frogs
review.abstract: Graph coloring, also known as vertex coloring, considers the problem of assigning colors to the nodes of a graph such that adjacent nodes do not share the same color. The optimization version of the problem concerns the minimization of the number of used colors. In this paper we deal with the problem of finding valid colorings of graphs in a distributed way, that is, by means of an algorithm that only uses local information for deciding the color of the nodes. Such algorithms prescind from any central control. Due to the fact that quite a few practical applications require to find colorings in a distributed way, the interest in distributed algorithms for graph coloring has been growing during the last decade. As an example consider wireless ad-hoc and sensor networks, where tasks such as the assignment of frequencies or the assignment of TDMA slots are strongly related to graph coloring.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 101 1,53 49v1 [cs.AI] 2The algorithm proposed in this paper is inspired by the call behavior of Japanese tree frogs. Male frogs use their calls to attract females. Interestingly, groups of males that are close to each other desynchronize their calls. This is because female frogs can only correctly locate male frogs when their calls are not too close to time. We have experimentally demonstrated that our algorithm is very competitive with the current state of the art by using various problem cases and comparing it with one of the most competitive algorithms in literature.

This parameter is selected in the first round of communication of phase II with a positive random integer for the nodes i with ci = 1 and 0 for the rest of the nodes. sections.heading: 3.3 Determining and Storing the Best Coloring Found
sections.text: It is intuitively clear that the current coloring of our system - that is, the coloring defined by ci colors for all nodes i - is not only improved over time. In some rounds of communication, especially in the second phase of the algorithm, the new coloring after the choice of new colors will actually be worse than the coloring of the previous round of communication. This behavior is very natural because the search space of a combinatorial optimization problem is characterized by quite a lot of local minima. If we assume that the current solution corresponds to such a local minimum, the only way to find a better solution for some iterations is to accept worse solutions for some iterations. In the context of metaheuristic algorithms, such an action is known as escape from a local minimum. sections.heading: 4.3 Results for Grid Topologies
sections.text: They can all be painted as a chessboard that requires only two colors. For example, see Figure 8. The way in which optimal coloring can easily be achieved is to start the coloring process in a single knot with the first color, and then proceed step by step. The next step is to color all neighbors of the start knot in the second color. All neighbors of these knots must be painted again in the first color, and so on. However, when looking at distributed calculations, the knots only have local information, whereas information about the position in the grid is missing. Moreover, the incremental process described above is difficult to achieve without global control. So, when grids are colored in a distributed way, what usually happens is that the coloring process is initiated in several different knots. If the coloring of these knots does not follow the distribution of colors, additional colors are ultimately required.

sections.heading: 4.4 Results for Small Instances from [27]
sections.text: Finally, we present the results obtained by the three algorithms for rather small cases used by S. Lee in [27] to evaluate a firefly-inspired, distributed graph staining algorithm. We do not directly compare them with the results presented in [27], because the algorithm suggests [27] that the number of colors required for coloring is a priori known, that is, the algorithm must be executed for a predetermined number of colors. If graphs are large and chromatic numbers are unknown, such an algorithm is impractical. In any case, FrogSim and the algorithm from [27] behave very similar behavior for most instances, with some exceptions: for hexagon-based instances, FrogSim is not quite able to surpass the average results obtained by the algorithm from [27].

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: Graph coloring is a classic problem of modern mathematics with more than 150 years of history. In addition, the problem has been extensively studied in theory and practice. However, its connection to problems arising with the proliferation of wireless networks has aroused a particular interest in solving the problem in a distributed way. In such algorithms - due to the lack of global knowledge - the nodes must base their color selection solely on information obtained from their immediate neighborhood.The algorithm we have presented in this paper is inspired by the behavior of a family of frogs native to Japan, namely the calling behavior of Japanese tree frogs. The results obtained by the proposed algorithm compare very favorably with current state-of-the-art algorithms. In particular, improved performance has been measured for about 90% of the instances studied. The benchmark set we have selected for comparison includes random geometric graphs, most of the graphs of the DIMACS problem, and we need wireless grid results to be very conducive to the other graphs, in addition to the proposed diagrams.

metadata.abstractText: Graph coloring—also known as vertex coloring—considers the problem of assigning colors to the nodes of a graph such that adjacent nodes do not share the same color. The optimization version of the problem concerns the minimization of the number of used colors. In this paper we deal with the problem of finding valid colorings of graphs in a distributed way, that is, by means of an algorithm that only uses local information for deciding the color of the nodes. Such algorithms prescind from any central control. Due to the fact that quite a few practical applications require to find colorings in a distributed way, the interest in distributed algorithms for graph coloring has been growing during the last decade. As an example consider wireless ad-hoc and sensor networks, where tasks such as the assignment of frequencies or the assignment of TDMA slots are strongly related to graph coloring. The algorithm proposed in this paper is inspired by the calling behavior of Japanese tree frogs. Male frogs use their calls to attract females. Interestingly, groups of males that are located nearby each other desynchronize their calls. This is because female frogs are only able to correctly localize the male frogs when their calls are not too close in time. We experimentally show that our algorithm is very competitive with the current state of the art, using different sets of problem instances and comparing to one of the most competitive algorithms from the literature.
